intro.intro_para_1: I'm a frontend developer, optimist, and community builder. I currently work as the software developer at Easebuzz, where I help teach the Next.js community, an open-source web framework built with React.
intro.intro_para_2: I create educational content for developers, writing about web development, JavaScript and TypeScript, React and Next.js, and more. This comes in all forms: blog posts, videos, tweets, conference talks, and workshops. You can watch some of my favorites below.
intro.intro_para_3: Over the past decade, I've written content on my blog and newsletter. I try to keep things simple. You'll find writing about technologies I'm interested in at the time, or how I'm learning and growing in my career, sharing knowledge along the way.

title.title_1: What makes a great developer experience?

Work.work_para_1: On a mission to build products developers love, and along the way, teach the next generation of developers. Here's a summary of my work so far.

Current.title: Software Developer
Current.info_para_1: I joined Easebuzz early to grow Next.js and our developer community. I built our Developer Relations team to teach our community about our products.
job_points: In 2022, I was hired to create a scalable and robust mobile application which was available on iOS and android. .

In 2022, I was promoted to VP of Developer Experience, now also leading our product documentation team. My team created a new free course to teach Next.js, which had 17 million page views that year. I shipped. I partnered with our open-source community, collaborating with frameworks like Nuxt and Astro and sponsoring individuals and projects.
In 2023, I was promoted to VP of Product, now also leading Product Management.
Current.info_para_2: Since I joined Easebuzz in 2022, ePOS active users have grown 1000%, now at ~100k. Next.js is now a top 10 software project on GitHub with 124k stars. It's used by Walmart, ChatGPT, Starbucks, Okta,Datastax, Notion, and more.

prev_job_info: Hy-Vee, an almost 100-year-old grocery chain in the United States, wanted to build a new version of their digital storefront. I joined a team of product engineers working across web and mobile to rebuild their legacy .NET application (~500k MAU) with React and React Native.

On the frontend, I led our move from a custom webpack and React configuration to Next.js and the latest React patterns. In the process, I shared my learnings online, helping educate members of the React and Next.js community by creating courses.

Throughout my two years, I was able to work on some hard problems: decoupling a decade old monolith into microservices, working with a federated GraphQL API, learning and occasionally managing a Kubernetes cluster, building and implementing a design system, incrementally migrating individual components and routes to a new framework and infrastructure, and more.

Workiva ($WK) is a cloud platform for data reporting and compliance. During my time at Workiva, I gained my first production experience using React. I worked on tooling to help predict and alert and regressions in our SaaS platform, building a product similar to open-source tools like Sentry.
